author: The Herald
title: Minister scoffs at hunger deaths claims
text: Minister scoffs at hunger deaths claims KAMPALA. – A Ugandan government minister is facing criticism after calling those who have died of hunger in his country “idiots”. Many have deemed Henry Okello Oryem’s comments tone-deaf. In 2022, more than 2,200 people died of starvation and related illnesses in north-east Uganda, a report by an official human rights body said. But Mr Oryem argued that given Uganda’s favourable climate and fertile land, people should be able to grow food for themselves. “It’s only an idiot, a real idiot, that can die of hunger in Uganda,” the state minister for foreign affairs told the NTV Uganda television channel. “If you work hard, there is land in Uganda. The climate is right in spite [of] climate change. If you make a double effort to make sure that you go out in the morning, you till your land, you plant the seeds, you maintain your plantation, surely, how do you fail then to get food?” As well as killing many people, the food shortage in the north-east left nearly half-a-million people in “acute hunger”, said the report by the Uganda Human Rights Commission, which was established by the constitution. – BBC.com

author: Andrew Vasquez
title: George Pickens’ injury proves Steelers made Roman Wilson-sized mistake
text:
The worries of Steelers fans have been confirmed: George Pickens has been ruled OUT for the Pittsburgh Steelers’ Week 16 AFC North showdown with the Baltimore Ravens .
However, his absence from last week’s and this week’s games provides ammunition to the season-long argument regarding the Steelers’ wide receiver room: HC Mike Tomlin and OC Arthur Smith need to give rookie WR Roman Wilson a chance.
It was recently argued by Steelers insider Gerry Dulac that Wilson’s inability to stay healthy during training camp and practices early on in 2024 forced the team to move on from his contributions this year. However, Pickens’ absence should force the team to reconsider.
In the past two games Pickens has missed, QB Russell Wilson struggled to find production out of his receivers and threw for a combined 286 yards in Weeks 14 and 15.
Regardless of Tomlin claiming to have “moved on,” or any insiders believing the rookie receiver will get his chance in 2025, one thing remains certain—the Wilson-to-Wilson connection could be the much-needed medicine for this dying Pittsburgh Steelers offense.
Articles Is T.J. Watt playing this week? Injury updates for Steelers EDGE Steelers QB injury changes the dynamic of offense vs Ravens Is George Pickens playing this week? Injury updates for Steelers WR

author: iCrowdMarketing
title: Building Foundations: How Innovative Preschool Programs Impact Early Childhood Development
text:
In today’s fast-evolving world of learning and development, parents and educators can’t overstate the significance of preschool in shaping a child’s future success. When it comes to options for
child care in Olney MD, innovative preschool programs are leaving a mark on the lives of young learners in and around Brooke Grove. That’s largely due to the critical role played by such programs in the overall development of preschool-aged children, blending daycare and childcare into a seamless educational experience.
Setting the Stage for Success
Early childhood educators unanimously agree that preschools lay the foundation for a child’s success in educational, personal, and professional spheres.
Olney child care programs go beyond conventional approaches, ensuring that preschool-aged children receive foundational care and attention crucial for establishing a robust developmental base. The program’s core lies in the Creative Curriculum®, a teaching strategy endorsed by the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE), which tailors individualized attention to each child in alignment with developmentally approved guidelines.
The implementation of The Creative Curriculum® at Brooke Grove spans a diverse spectrum of developmental needs. From Social-Emotional and Physical development to Language, Cognitive, Literacy, Mathematics, Science and Technology, Social Studies, the Arts, and English Language Acquisition; the program focuses on nurturing every facet of a child’s growth. This comprehensive approach ensures that children are not only academically prepared but also equipped with the confidence needed for the next steps in their academic journey.
School Readiness: Beyond ABCs and 123s
While the curriculum is play-based – a focus loved by preschoolers, it transcends traditional preschool age learning and development approaches. Children attending
daycare in Olney MD actively engage in group activities, learning essential skills such as sharing toys and books, expressing emotions, and collaborating with their peers.
And although play is at the heart of the preschool, it’s not just about fun and games. Attendees gain a host of other invaluable life skills:
– Teamwork: Sharing toys and books, cooperating with peers, and resolving conflicts.
– Emotional Intelligence: Understanding and expressing emotions effectively.
– Community Engagement: Appreciating their place in the world and valuing diversity.
The preschool program is not just about academic readiness; it is a holistic approach to child development that prepares children for the challenges of formal education while nurturing their individual strengths. The program ensures that these youngsters are school-ready in every other sense too:
– Confidence: Children emerge with the confidence needed to take that next step in their academic journey.
– Emotional Resilience: They learn to express themselves, collaborate, and work with others—a crucial skill set for life.
– Social Skills: Group activities teach sharing, empathy, and cooperation.
– Curiosity: The play-based approach sparks curiosity, setting the stage for lifelong learning.
These seemingly simple traits are, in fact, building blocks for the future, imparting invaluable social and emotional skills that children will carry with them throughout their lives. And, for parents and guardians entrusting their preschool-aged children to Brooke Grove, the assurance of receiving comprehensive care, support, and guidance is paramount.
Building a Future Generation
Olney child care programs don’t just prepare children for school; they empower them for life’s remarkable journey. The preschool age program is a place where young minds flourish, friendships bloom, and futures take shape. I fact, these innovative daycare programs are instrumental in nurturing the next generation of thinkers, dreamers, and achievers!

author: Vatican News
title: Angélus: l'Eucharistie nous invite à faire de notre vie un don pour les autres
text:
Angélus: l'Eucharistie nous invite à faire de notre vie un don pour les autres
Vatican news
Malgré un ciel gris et pluvieux, des centaines de fidèles munis de parapluie étaient réunis place Saint-Pierre ce dimanche matin en cette journée de célébration de la solennité du Corpus Christi. Depuis la fenêtre de ses appartements pontificaux, le Pape s’est arrêté sur l’Évangile de la liturgie du jour consacré à la dernière Cène de Jésus (Mc 14, 12-26). Dans cet épisode de la Bible, Jésus accomplit le geste de se livrer. «En effet, a expliqué François, dans le pain rompu et dans la coupe offerte aux disciples, c'est lui-même qui se donne pour toute l'humanité et qui s'offre pour la vie du monde».
Le don du Christ
Le Pape a ensuite souligné l’utilisation du verbe «donner», résonnant avec l’Eucharistie qui «rappelle avant tout la dimension du don». C’est en rompant et donnant le pain que Jésus révèle «son identité et sa mission». «Il n'a pas retenu la vie pour lui, mais il nous l'a donnée; il n'a pas considéré son être Dieu comme un trésor jaloux, mais il s'est dépouillé de sa gloire pour partager notre humanité et nous faire entrer dans la vie éternelle» (cf. Ph 2,1-11), a déclaré le Saint-Père.
Célébrer pleinement l’Eucharistie
François a ainsi invité les fidèles, célèbrant l’Eucharistie et mangeant le Pain chaque dimanche, à ne pas vivre cela comme «un acte de culte détaché de la vie ou un simple moment de consolation personnelle» mais comme «la communion avec Lui [qui] nous rend capables de devenir nous aussi le pain rompu pour les autres, de partager ce que nous sommes et ce que nous avons». Le Souverain pontife a ensuite rappelé les mots de Saint Léon le Grand, théologien et pasteur qui fut Pape de 440 à 461: «Notre participation au corps et au sang du Christ est de nous transformer en ce que nous consommons» (Sermon XII sur la Passion, 7).
Faire de sa vie un don pour l’autre
Le Pape a exhorté à devenir «ce que nous mangeons, devenir "eucharistiques", c’est-à-dire des personnes qui ne vivent plus pour elles-mêmes (cf. Rm 14,7), dans la logique de la possession et de la consommation, mais qui savent faire de leur vie un don pour les autres». «Ainsi, a-t-il poursuivi, grâce à l'Eucharistie, nous devenons prophètes et bâtisseurs d'un monde nouveau: lorsque nous dépassons l'égoïsme et que nous nous ouvrons à l'amour, lorsque nous cultivons les liens de fraternité, lorsque nous partageons les souffrances de nos frères et que nous partageons notre pain et nos ressources avec ceux qui sont dans le besoin, lorsque nous mettons nos talents à la disposition de tous, alors nous rompons le pain de notre vie à la manière de Jésus».
François a conclu sa prière de l’Angélus en invitant chacun à se poser les questions suivantes: «est-ce que je garde ma vie uniquement pour moi ou est-ce que je la donne comme Jésus l'a fait? Est-ce que je me dépense pour les autres ou est-ce que je me renferme sur moi-même? Et, dans les situations quotidiennes, est-ce que je sais partager ou est-ce que je cherche toujours mon propre intérêt?».
Merci d'avoir lu cet article. Si vous souhaitez rester informé, inscrivez-vous à la lettre d’information en
[ cliquant ici](/fr/inscription-newsletter.html)
